pageContext.claim: “And we walk from the White House. And I think, everything was handled very well. I will tell you, religious leaders loved it. Religious leaders thought it was great. They loved it.”
pageContext.analysis: Mainstream religious leaders criticized Trump for posing outside St. John's Episcopal Church with a Bible in hand, which came after authorities used tear gas and non-lethal munitions to disperse peaceful protesters in the vicinity, though he did receive some praise from the religious right. “Saint Pope John Paul II was an ardent defender of the rights and dignity of human beings. His legacy bears vivid witness to that truth," said Catholic Archbishop Wilton Gregory of Washington. "He certainly would not condone the use of tear gas and other deterrents to silence, scatter or intimidate them for a photo opportunity in front of a place of worship and peace.” The Right Rev. Mariann Budde, bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Washington, excoriated Trump for standing in front of the historic Episcopal church while holding the Bible aloft. “Everything he has said and done is to inflame violence,” Budde said. “We need moral leadership, and he’s done everything to divide us.”
